revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Lamar Hunt Jr. | image = Lamarhuntjr-750xx733.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Lamar Hunt Jr | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|10|20}} | birth_place = [[Dallas, Texas]], U.S. | occupation = Franchise Owner & President of [[Kansas City Mavericks]] Founder Loretto Companies | alma mater = University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music | known for = Owner of the [[Kansas City Mavericks]] ice hockey team, advisory board member for the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] | spouse = Rita Mae Hammerschmidt Hunt (m. 2003) | children = 7 }}
'''Lamar Hunt Jr.''' (born October 20, 1956) is an American businessman, entrepreneur, sports promoter, and philanthropist. Lamar is president and owner of the [[Kansas City Mavericks]] professional hockey team. He is the son of [[Lamar Hunt]], grandson of oil tycoon [[H. L. Hunt|H.L. Hunt]], and part of the founding and operating family of the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] [[National Football League|NFL]] team.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://cdn.espn.go.com/blog/kansas-city-chiefs/post/_/id/10986/kansas-city-chiefs-ownership-at-a-glance|title=Kansas City Chiefs Ownership at a Glance|last=Teicher|first=Adam|date=March 18, 2015|work=ESPN.com|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Lamar Hunt Jr. played flute<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article55801410.html|title=Lamar Hunt Jr. {{!}} Faith, Forgiveness and Hockey|last=Adler|first=Eric|date=January 21, 2016|work=Kansas City Star|access-date=2017-06-08|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> for the [[Kansas City Symphony]], and worked as a Licensed Professional Counselor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://npino.com/counselor/1457531329-lamar--hunt-jr./|title=Lamar Hunt Jr., Professional Counselor {{!}} NPI 1457531329|last=|first=|date=|website=npino.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref> He donates his time, energy, and resources to countless charities helping to promote family and improve the lives of those who are less fortunate through Loretto Companies.
== Early life & education == Lamar Hunt Jr. was born to [[Lamar Hunt|Lamar]] and Rose Mary Whittle Hunt on October 20, 1956.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article55801410.html|title=Lamar Hunt Jr.: Faith, forgiveness and hockey|last=|first=|date=|work=Kansas City Star|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> He grew up in Dallas, Texas, where he spent the first 11 years of his life. Lamar and Rose Mary Hunt separated when Lamar Hunt Jr. was five years old and divorced In the summer of 1963. His childhood was spent between both parents, his father and his father's new wife, Norma Knobel, whom he married in 1964<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/15/sports/football/15hunt.html|title=Lamar Hunt, a Force in Football, Dies at 74|last=Eskenazi|first=Gerald|date=2006-12-15|work=The New York Times|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> and his mother and her new husband, a Texas businessman named John David Carr.
As a young man, Lamar Hunt Jr. attended private school at [[St. Mark's School of Texas]], an all-boys school located in North [[Dallas]]. During his tenure at St. Mark's, Lamar Hunt Jr. played football, basketball, track, and tennis. Lamar Hunt Jr. showed an early aptitude for music learning to play the flute and a bit of piano. Lamar Hunt Jr.'s interest in music continued throughout his time at St. Mark's, where he played [[flute]] as a member of the band and orchestra. After graduating from high school, Lamar Hunt Jr. auditioned for five different colleges that were known for their music programs, ultimately choosing the [[University of Cincinnati – College-Conservatory of Music|University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music]] (UCCCM).
During his time at UCCCM, Lamar Hunt Jr. performed in a number of different types of ensembles and continued to refine his musical talents while also pursuing his interests in other academic pursuits. Years later, Lamar Hunt Jr. would return to school as a graduate student at [[Dallas Baptist University]] from 2001 through 2003, where he studied cognitive-behavioral therapy and received a Master of Arts in Counseling in May 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://npino.com/counselor/1457531329-lamar--hunt-jr./|title=Lamar Hunt Jr., Counselor - Professional in Leawood - NPI 1457531329, Contact and Address|last=|first=|date=November 8, 2007|website=NPI NO|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date= |deadurl=no |accessdate=June 10, 2017}}</ref>
== Music career == While in high school, Hunt Jr. studied with a musician from the [[Dallas Symphony Orchestra|Dallas Symphony]] and fell in love with classical music, a passion that has followed him throughout his life. After graduating from the [[University of Cincinnati – College-Conservatory of Music|University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music]] in 1979, Lamar Hunt Jr. auditioned for the [[Kansas City Symphony]] and earned the position of second flute in the orchestra.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/44060179/|title=Lamar Hunt Jr. To Perform with Symphony|last=|first=|date=November 28, 1979|work=Irving Daily News|access-date=|archive-url= |archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
Hunt Jr. performed with the Kansas City Symphony for ten years while teaching flute at the [[University of Missouri–Kansas City]] (UMKC), as well as private flute lessons both in his home and at the Music-Arts Institute located in Independence, Missouri. Along with several other musicians and members of the orchestra, Lamar Hunt Jr. helped to start Summerfest Concerts,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/classical-music-dance/article25500373.html|title=The Classical Beat: The sweet sounds of Summerfest|last=Neas|first=Patrick|date=June 28, 2015|work=Kansas City Star|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> a chamber music series that recently celebrated its 25th season.
Lamar Hunt Jr.'s notable performances include performing [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach's]] [[Brandenburg Concertos|Brandenburg Concerto No. 4]] at the [[Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art]] to a standing-room-only crowd in a collaboration between the orchestra and the [[The King's Singers|King Singers]] that was recorded and shown nationally on [[PBS]] stations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/465238/King-s-Singers-Holiday-Special-With-the-Kansas-City-Symphony-The/|title=King's Singers' Holiday Special With the Kansas City Symphony|last=|first=|date=|website=Turner Classic Movies|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref> Lamar Hunt Jr. also recorded an album at St. James Cahtholic Church in Liberty, MO of Bach's flute sonatas in 1990.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/lamar-hunt-jr-lamar-hunt-jr/albums|title=Lamar Hunt Jr. - Sonata for Flute {{!}} Johann Sebastian Bach|last=|first=|date=October 26, 1990|website=SoundCloud|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Lamar Hunt Jr. continues to support music in the Kansas City community today{{when|date=April 2018}} as an active board member with the Kansas City Symphony.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kcsymphony.org/StaticCtl/BoardOfDirectorsAct|title=Board of Directors|last=|first=|date=July 13, 2016|website=www.kcsymphony.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Professional career == As a founder of Loretto Companies, Lamar Hunt Jr. has four distinct ventures, all dedicated to serving the Kansas City community in various ways. The Loretto Companies were named for the staircase at [[Loretto Chapel]] in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]]. The story goes that when the [[Sisters of Loreto|Sisters of Loretto]] finished the chapel, they realized that there was no good way to access the choir loft. The answer to their prayers came when a visiting gentleman offered to engineer and build a staircase for the sisters. After completing the project he left silently without receiving any payment. What he left behind was an architectural marvel that is still visited today. Like that visiting architect, the mission of the Loretto Companies is not recognition or recompense but to help others for the sake of helping them.
The [http://lorettofoundation.com/ Loretto Foundation] helps to build strong families and encourage spiritual growth by focusing on Catholic grade schools<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thehighlandsschool.org/campus-life/lamar-hunt-jr-family-field-dedicated-and-blessed/|title=Lamar Hunt, Jr. Family Field Dedicated and Blessed|last=|first=|date=May 25, 2017|website=The Highlands School Org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wyandottedaily.com/bishop-ward-fund-to-receive-400000-gift/|title=Bishop Ward Fund to Receive $400,000 Gift From Lamar Hunt Jr., Loretto Foundation|last=Sukraw|first=Josh|date=October 31, 2016|website=Wyandotte Daily|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and high schools<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stasaints.net/apps/news/article/620244|title=Rita and Lamar Hunt, Jr, present cash gift for Aquinas 2020|website=www.stasaints.net|language=en|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref> in the greater Kansas City area. Other organizations, including the Bright Futures Fund, Ozanam,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sbwire.com/press-releases/lamar-hunt-jr/release-635815.htm|title=Lamar Hunt Jr. and Loretto Foundation Support Ozanam|last=Brockton|first=|date=October 23, 2015|work=SB Wire|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> Children's Center for the Visually Impaired, and Variety KC are also active charities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thenorthlandnews.com/missouri-mavericks-variety-kc-team-can-play-2/|title=Loretto Foundation and Variety KC Team Up for “We Can Play 2!”|last=|first=|date=December 6, 2016|work=The Northland News|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> Lamar Hunt Jr.'s dedication to music isn't left out of the mix, either, as the Loretto Foundation also contributes to the Bluegrass Heritage Foundation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/pr/2680856|title=Bluegrass Heritage Foundation Supported by Lamar Hunt Jr. and the Loretto Foundation|last=Lewis|first=Lauren|date=September 21, 2015 |website=DigitalJournal.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Under Loretto Commercial, Hunt Jr. works to develop commercial projects that thrive and are sustainable, in order to add to the quality of life in Kansas City.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/kansascity/news/2014/06/02/downtown-kck-revitalization-lamar-hunt-jr.html|title=Lamar Hunt Jr. kicks off downtown KCK revitalization effort|last=Roberts|first=Rob|date=June 2, 2014|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Loretto Sports Ventures is closely tied to the [[Kansas City Mavericks]] [[ECHL]] hockey franchise,<ref name=":0" /> with a current overall goal of growing the game of [[ice hockey]] in Kansas City and engaging more young people to pick up the sport. Another goal of Loretto Sports Ventures is to help make Kansas City a destination for ice hockey among travel teams across the Midwest while also bringing the highest level of youth hockey to the marketplace.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/blog/2015/09/lamar-hunt-jr-enjoys-the-great-disease-of-sports.html|title=Lamar Hunt Jr. enjoys ‘the great disease of sports investing’|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref> Loretto Sports Ventures also purchased the Topeka RoadRunners, a [[Junior ice hockey|junior hockey]] team, that was then renamed [[Topeka Pilots]] in 2018.<ref name="RoadRunners">{{cite web |url=https://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/loretto-sports-ventures-purchases-nahls-topeka-roadrunners/n-5320235 |title=Loretto Sports Ventures Purchases NAHL's Topeka RoadRunners |website=OurSportsCentral.com |date=April 18, 2018}}</ref>
Loretto Properties is a commercial and residential real estate development company<ref name=":1" /> dedicated to building projects of all types without leaving behind those communities where the citizens are most vulnerable.
Lamar Hunt Jr. has been asked to speak to a variety of groups within the business community—not to mention students who might want to learn from the experience that he has gathered. Highlights include speaking to the Overland Park Chamber of Commerce<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cca.opchamber.org/EvtListing.aspx?dbid2=ksop&keyword=777719&class=E|title=Executive Leadership Series Featuring Lamar Hunt, Jr.|last=|first=|date=October 4, 2016|website=OPchamber.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref> about leadership.
== Sports teams == Lamar Hunt Jr. extended the Hunt family sports legacy by purchasing the Missouri Mavericks ice hockey team in January 2015,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kctv5.com/story/28049421/lamar-hunt-jr-buys-missouri-mavericks-hockey-team|title=Lamar Hunt Jr. Buys Missouri Mavericks Hockey Team |date=February 6, 2015|work=KCTV 5 News |archive-url=|archive-date= |language=en |deadurl=no |accessdate=June 10, 2017}}</ref> which became the [[Kansas City Mavericks]] in June 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.examiner.net/sports/20170311/mavericks-to-change-name-to-kansas-city-mavericks-on-june-1|title=Mavericks to change name to Kansas City Mavericks on June 1|last=Althaus|first=Bill|date=March 11, 2017|work=Examiner|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> He later purchased the [[Topeka RoadRunners]] in 2018.<ref name="RoadRunners"/>
In addition to owning the Mavericks, Lamar Hunt Jr. is part of the founding and operating family of the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] [[National Football League|NFL]] team.<ref name=":2" /> Hunt Jr. enjoys a beneficial interest in the Hunt Family Foundation as a way to be further involved and give back to the community in ways both big and small. The Foundation has teamed up with Tyson Chicken and Harvesters to help address hunger and also sponsor a mentoring program for at-risk kids.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/kansascitychiefs/docs/33967_2015-chiefsincommunity_spread|title=Kansas City Chiefs Hunger Relief Community Report 2014-2015|last=Kansas City Chiefs|first=|date=April 30, 2015|work=ISSU.com|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
== Board memberships & charities == Lamar Hunt Jr. also commits time to serving on a number of different advisory boards as another way to lend a hand and give back to the communities that have meant so much to him. Over the years, Lamar Hunt Jr. has served on school boards, Dynamic Catholic Board of Directors,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://dynamiccatholic.com/our-mission/board-of-directors/#lamar|title=Board of Directors - The Dynamic Catholic Institute|work=The Dynamic Catholic Institute|access-date=2017-06-08|language=en-US}}</ref> and the board for [http://huntmidwest.com/about-hunt-midwest/ownership-leadership/ Hunt Midwest Enterprises], to name a few.
Hunt Jr. also serves on the Catholic Radio Network founded by Jim O'Laughlin in 2004. As a member of the advisory board and an underwritter,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecatholicradionetwork.com/services2|title=The Catholic Radio Network - Underwriters|last=|first=|date=|website=The Catholic Radio Network|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-08}}</ref> his involvement has helpedgrown to include 17 stations all over Kansas, Missouri, and Colorado.
Hunt Midwest Enterprises (HME) is part of the legacy left behind by [[Lamar Hunt|Lamar Hunt's]] desire to invest in and give back to the Kansas City community. Lamar Hunt Jr. stewards this heritage as an active board member in projects that match its core values of quality, integrity, safety, and service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140417006127/en/LightEdge-Solutions-Hunt-Midwest-Celebrate-Opening-Kansas|title=Hunt Midwest Celebrates Opening of New Kansas City Data Center|last=Hagen|first=Debbie|date=April 17, 2014|website=www.businesswire.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Lamar Hunt Jr. evaluates the various projects presented to him by Hunt Midwest's management team and helps to develop the vision that was established by his father.
Hunt Jr. also volunteered with the Archbishop's Case Review Task Force, which examined the major needs in the Archdiocese of Kansas City in Kansas in order to come up with approaches and fundraising solutions that helped meet some urgent needs. In 2012, the Task Force completed a private appeal campaign and raised $14 million for various projects in the Kansas City area.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=January 6, 2012|title=Archbishop’s Case Review Task Force Final Report and Recommendations|url=https://www.archkck.org/document.doc?id=1200|journal=The Archdiocese of Kansas City in Kansas|volume=|pages=37|via=}}</ref>
Lamar Hunt Jr. also gives his time, resources, and support to charities, organizations, and programs such as the Bright Futures Fund,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article57111728.html|title=Former Derrick Thomas Academy to Become Home to New Catholic Elementary School|last=|first=|date=January 28, 2016|work=Kansas City Star|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> which helps provide scholarships for students in need to attend Catholic schools throughout the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph without a financial barrier. The Bright Futures Fund helps students to discover their potential, build a foundation of social justice, and develop a personal relationship with Jesus Christ. The fund also helps build a community where families feel safe and welcome and schools that engage both students and their parents in their educational journey.
He has also participated in Read Across America, a program in which adults simply give up a part of their day to read to children at schools. Lamar Hunt Jr. participated in both Independence, Missouri and Columbus, Ohio and found the experience to be very moving. "Reading is so fundamental and important that any adult can be a role model for children in this critical life skill," he says. "I was told that, as a male, reading to students had a particularly great impact because so often fathers do not do this with their children."

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2013}}
The [[Law]] & Management approach is a term defined by Antoine Masson and Hugh Bouthinon-Dumas, researchers at ESSEC, to refer to any research works focusing on Law as a key factor for companies success.<ref name="RTDcom">A. Masson, H. Bouthinon-Dumas, L’approche Law and Management, ''RTD Com'', janvier /mars 2011, p. 233 à 254.</ref>
The Law & Management approach, unlike the Economic Analysis of Law (also known as "Law and Economics") which primarily aims at assessing and comparing the cost and efficiency of the rules in accordance with criterium developed by Economists, seeks to explain the differences of performance between companies facing the same legal environment, according to their ability to take advantage from Law.
From a methods perspective, the Law & Management approach focuses on the behaviors of economic actors towards Law. The Law & Management methods are therefore primarily behavioral and borrow numerous investigation and data processing techniques from the [[sociology]] or [[psychology]] fields since these approaches rely on observation. The purpose of the Law & Management is nevertheless specific and consistent with management sciences, as it try to understand how Law can be used by (and within) companies to achieve their assigned goals (that are mainly economic). The results of Law & Management studies can be used to base recommendations that are addressed primarily not to normative or judicial authorities (as in the Law & Economic) but to the economic actors.
Currently, the Law & Management approach refers to the legal work of authors such as, in the United States, Constance Bagley ([[Yale School of Management]]),<ref name="Winning Legally">, C. E. Bagley, Winning ''Legally: How to Use the Law to Create Value, Marshal Resources, and Manage Risk, Harvard Business School Press'', 2005, spec. pp. 47–50.</ref> Robert Bird ([[University of Connecticut]]),<ref name="Pathways of Legal Strategy ">, R. Bird, Pathways of Legal Strategy, ''14 STAN. J.L, BUS, & FIN.'' (2008), p. 1.</ref> George Siedel (Michigan Business School),<ref name="Using Law for Competitive Advantage">, G. J. Siedel, ''Using Law for Competitive Advantage'', Jossey Bass, 2002.</ref> in [[Scandinavia]] (around the "proactive law” movement) Haapio Helena ([[University of Vaasa]]),<ref name="Introduction to Praoactive Law ">, H. Haapio, Introduction to Praoactive Law : A Business Lawyer's View, ''Scandinavian Studies in Law'', vol. 49, 2010, p. 21.</ref> or in [[France]], Christophe Roquilly (EDHEC),<ref name="Performance juridique et avantage concurrentiel ">, Ch. Roquilly, « Performance juridique et avantage concurrentiel », LPA, 30 avril 2007, n° 86, p. 7.</ref> Christophe Collard (EDHEC),<ref name="La performance juridique">, C. Collard, C. Roquilly, La performance juridique : pour une vision stratégique du droit dans l'entreprise, L.G.D.J., 2010</ref> Antoine Masson (ESSEC) ou Hugues Bouthinon-Dumas (ESSEC).
==References== <references />

=== Canada === * [[Canadian Co-operative Association]] (CCA) * Canadian Worker Co-operative Federation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianworker.coop |accessdate=February 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160211105335/http://canadianworker.coop/ |archivedate=February 11, 2016 }}</ref> (CWCF) * [[Conseil Canadien de la Coopération]] (CCC) * [[Federated Co-operatives]] * [[Fédération québécoise des coopératives en milieu scolaire]] * [[Ontario Co-operative Association]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ontario.coop |title=On Co-op - The Ontario Co-operative Association |website=Ontario.coop |date=2015-06-26 |accessdate=2016-02-10}}</ref>
=== Mexico === * [[Caja Libertad S.C.L]]. * [[Caja Popular Mexicana]] * [[Confederación Nacional de Cooperativas de Actividades Diversas]] (CNC) * [[Federación de Cajas Populares Alianza S.C. de R.L. de C.V.]] * [[Federación Nacional de Cooperativas Financieras UNISAP S.C. de R.L. de C.V.]]
=== United States === * [[ACDI/VOCA]] * [[CF Industries]] (demutualized 2005) * [[CHF International]] * [[CHS, Inc.]] * [[CUNA Mutual Group]] * [[Credit Union National Association]] (CUNA) * [[Farmland Industries]] (liquidated 2003) * [[National Cooperative Bank]] (NCB) * [[National Cooperative Business Association]] (NCBA) (formerly the Cooperative League of America) * [[National Cooperative Grocers Association]] (NCGA) * [[National Rural Electric Cooperative Association]] (NRECA) * [[Network of Bay Area Worker Cooperatives]] (NoBAWC) * [[Northern States Co-operative League]] (NSCL, established 1921) * [[Philadelphia Area Cooperative Alliance]] (PACA) * [[Portland Alliance of Worker Cooperatives]] (PAWC) * [[U.S. Federation of Worker Cooperatives]] (USFWC) * [[Valley Alliance of Worker Cooperatives]]

=== Bulgaria === * [[Central Co-operative Union]] (CCU) * [[National Union of Workers Producers Co-operatives of Bulgaria]]

KG]] * [[Konsumverband eG]] * [[Zentralverband deutscher Konsumgenossenschaften]] (ZdK) * [[Union Coop - Föderation gewerkschaftlicher Kollektivbetriebe]] (Union Coop)

=== Moldova === * [[Union of Consumer Societies]]

= | twin1_country = | twin2 = | twin2_country = | blank_name_sec1 = | blank_info_sec1 = | blank1_name_sec1 = | blank1_info_sec1 = | blank2_name_sec1 = | blank2_info_sec1 = | blank_name_sec2 = | blank_info_sec2 = | blank1_name_sec2 = | blank1_info_sec2 = | blank2_name_sec2 = | blank2_info_sec2 = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Little Italy''' is a neighborhood in [[Lower Manhattan]], [[New York City]], once known for its large population of [[Italian Americans]].[http://www.lifeinitaly.com/heritage/little-italy.asp Little Italy | Italy] Today the neighborhood consists of only a few Italian stores and restaurants.[http://www.littleitalynyc.com/ Little Italy NYC - The Official Website for New York City's Little Italy District] It is bounded on the west by [[Tribeca]] and [[SoHo, Manhattan|Soho]], on the south by [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Chinatown]], on the east by the [[Bowery]] and [[Lower East Side]], and on the north by [[Nolita]]. ==History== Little Italy on [[Mulberry Street (Manhattan)|Mulberry Street]] used to extend as far south as [[Worth Street]], as far north as [[Houston Street]], as far west as [[Lafayette Street]], and as far east as [[Bowery]]. It is now only three blocks on Mulberry Street.{{cite news| url=https://nypost.com/2014/03/30/changing-times-pushing-little-italy-to-brink-of-extinction/ | work=New York Post | first=Kate | last=Briquelet | title=Little Italy is on the brink of extinction | date=March 30, 2014}} Little Italy originated as Mulberry Bend. [[Jacob Riis]] described Mulberry Bend as "the foul core of New York's slums."Tonelli, Bill. "Arrivederci, Little Italy." ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''. September 27, 2004. p. [http://nymag.com/nymetro/urban/features/9904/ 1]. Retrieved on April 10, 2013. During this time period "Immigrants of the late 19th century usually settled in ethnic neighborhoods".{{Cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of New York City|last=Jackson, Keller|first=Kenneth T, Lisa|publisher=University Press|year=2010|location=New Haven, US|pages=|quote=|via=Yale}} Therefore, the "mass immigration from Italy during the 1880's"{{Cite book|title=Multicultural America: A Multimedia Encyclopedia|last=Pretelli|first=Matteo|publisher=SAGE Reference|year=2014|isbn=|location=Thousand Oaks, CA|pages=1362–1363|quote=|via=Gale Virtual Reference Library}} led to the large settlement of Italian immigrants in lower Manhattan. The results of such migration had created an "influx of Italian immigrants" which had "led to the commercial gathering of their dwelling and business".{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Immigration and Migration in the American West|last=Henderson|first=Matthew Adam|publisher=SAGE Reference|year=2006|pages=411–413|via=Gale Virtual Reference Library}} Bill Tonelli from ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine said, "Once, Little Italy was like an insular Neapolitan village re-created on these shores, with its own language, customs, and financial and cultural institutions." Little Italy was not the largest Italian neighborhood in New York City, as [[East Harlem]] (or [[Italian Harlem]]) had a larger Italian population. Tonelli said that Little Italy "was perhaps the city's poorest Italian neighborhood". In 1910 Little Italy had almost 10,000 Italians; that was the peak of the community's Italian population. At the turn of the 20th century over 90% of the residents of the Fourteenth Ward were of Italian birth or origins. Tonnelli said that it meant "that residents began moving out to more spacious digs almost as soon as they arrived." Such a vastly growing community impacted the "U.S. labor movement in the 20th century" by making up much of the labor population in the garment industry". After [[World War II]], many residents of the [[Lower East Side]] began moving to [[Brooklyn]], [[Staten Island]], eastern [[Long Island]], and [[New Jersey]]. Chinese immigrants became an increased presence after the [[U.S. Immigration Act of 1965]] removed immigration restrictions, and the [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Manhattan Chinatown]] to Little Italy's south expanded. In 2004, Tonelli said, "You can go back 30 years and find newspaper clips chronicling the expansion of Chinatown and mourning the loss of Little Italy." Prior to 2004, several upscale businesses entered the northern portion of the area between Houston and Kenmare Street. Tonelli said "Real-estate prices zoomed, making it even tougher for the old-timers—residents and businesspeople alike—to hang on." After the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001, areas below Houston Street were cut off for the rest of the fall of 2001. The [[San Gennaro feast]], scheduled for September 13, was postponed. Business from the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] dropped severely, due to the closure of [[Park Row (Manhattan)|Park Row]], which connected Chinatown and the [[Civic Center, Manhattan|Civic Center]]; as a result, residents in Little Italy and Chinatown suffered. Tonelli said the post-9/11 events "strangely enough, ended up motivating all these newfangled efforts to save what's left of the old neighborhood." In 2004 Tonelli said "Today, Little Italy is a veneer—50 or so restaurants and cafés catering to tourists, covering a dense neighborhood of tenements shared by recent Chinese immigrants, young Americans who can't afford [[SoHo, Manhattan|Soho]], and a few remaining real live Italians." This sentiment has also been echoed by Italian culture and heritage website ''ItalianAware''. The site has called the dominance of Italians in the area, "relatively short lived." It attributes this to the quick financial prosperity many Italians achieved, which afforded them the opportunity to leave the cramped neighborhood for areas in Brooklyn and Queens. The site also goes on to state that the area is currently referred to as Little Italy more out of nostalgia than as a reflection of a true ethnic population.{{cite web|title=Littl-er Italy in NYC|url=http://italianaware.blogspot.com/2011/02/littler-italy-in-new-york.html|publisher=ItalianAware|accessdate=18 March 2014}} In 2010, Little Italy and [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Chinatown]] were listed in a single [[historic district (United States)|historic district]] on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].{{cite web|title=National Register of Historic Places listings for February 19, 2010|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/listings/20100219.htm|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|date=February 19, 2010|accessdate=February 19, 2010}} Little Italy, by this point, was shrinking rapidly. {{clear left}} =={{anchor|Demographics}} Historic and current demographics== [[File:Littleitaly worldcup.JPG|thumb|250px|People in Little Italy celebrating, one hour after the [[Italy national football team|Italian soccer team]] won the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]]] ''[[The New York Times]]'' sent its reporters to characterize the Little Italy/Mulberry neighborhood in May 1896:
They are laborers; toilers in all grades of manual work; they are artisans, they are junkman, and here, too, dwell the rag pickers. ... There is a monster colony of Italians who might be termed the commercial or shop keeping community of the Latins. Here are all sorts of stores, pensions, groceries, fruit emporiums, tailors, shoemakers, wine merchants, importers, musical instrument makers. ... There are notaries, lawyers, doctors, apothecaries, undertakers. ... There are more bankers among the Italians than among any other foreigners except the Germans in the city.Staff (May 31, 1896) "Little Italy in New-York" ''[[The New York Times]]'' p.32
As of the [[2000 U.S. Census]], 1,211 residents claiming Italian ancestry lived in three census tracts that make up Little Italy. Those residents comprise 8.25% of the population in the community, which is similar to the proportion of those of Italian ancestry throughout New York City. Bill Tonelli of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine contrasted Little Italy with the [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Manhattan Chinatown]]; in 2000, of the residents of the portions of Chinatown south of Grand Street, 81% were of Chinese origins. In 2004, Tonelli revisited the issue, saying, "Little Italy may always endure as an open-air theme park of nineteenth- and twentieth-century European immigration to the Lower East Side ... But you'll spend a long time in the neighborhood before you hear anyone speak Italian, and then the speaker will be a tourist from Milan."Tonelli, Bill. "Arrivederci, Little Italy." ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''. September 27, 2004. p. [http://nymag.com/nymetro/urban/features/9904/index1.html 2]. Retrieved on April 10, 2013. Tonelli added, "You have to slow your gaze to find the neighbors in this neighborhood, because they're so overwhelmed and outnumbered by the tourists. But once you focus, you can see them, standing (or sitting) in the interstices, taking in the scene, like the group of men, mostly senior citizens, loitering contentedly under an awning on Mulberry Street." ==Cultural attractions== [[File:Little Italy.JPG|thumb|250px|[[Mulberry Street (Manhattan)|Mulberry Street]] in Little Italy]] Little Italy was home to dozens of restaurants that serve authentic Italian cuisine, but between March 2013 and March 2014, eight eateries closed down.http://ny.eater.com/archives/2014/03/rent_hikes_forcing_little_italy_restaurants_to_close.php Since 2004, [[Sorrento Lactalis]] funds neighborhood cultural events in Little Italy. The Feast of San Gennaro originally was once only a one-day religious commemoration. It began in September 1926 with the new arrival of immigrants from Naples. The Italian immigrants congregated along Mulberry Street in Manhattan's ''Little Italy'' to celebrate [[San Gennaro]] as the Patron Saint of [[Naples]]. The ''Feast of San Gennaro'' is a large street fair, lasting 11 days, that takes place every September along Mulberry Street between Houston and Canal Streets.[http://www.italian-link.com/pages/littleitalynewyork.shtml Little Italy New York City] The festival is an annual celebration of [[Culture of Italy|Italian culture]] and the [[Italian-American]] community. In 1995 Mort Berkowitz became the professional manager of a community group that had been formed to take over management of the San Gennaro feast. Since then, Berkowitz became involved in other recreational activities in Little Italy, including the summer, [[Carnival|Carnevale]], [[Columbus Day]], and [[Christmas]] events. Richard Alba, a sociologist and professor at [[University at Albany, SUNY]], said, "The fascinating part here is the way in which ethnic tourism—not only by [[Italian Americans]] but by people who want to see an authentic urban village—keeps these neighborhoods going." ==Organized crime and the Mafia== Little Italy residents have seen organized crime since the early 20th century. Powerful members of the [[Italian-American Mafia|Italian Mafia]] have operated in ''Little Italy''. * [[Ignazio Saietta|Ignazio "The Wolf" Lupo]] (a [[Morello crime family]] boss operated in Little Italy from late 1890s-1920s) * [[Michele Miranda|Michele "Big Mike" Miranda]] (a [[Caporegime|Capo]] in the [[Genovese crime family]] operated in the neighborhood from the 1950s into the late 1960s) * [[Peter DeFeo]] (a ''Genovese crime family'' capo who operated an illegal ''Italian lottery'' in the 1960s into the 1970s) * [[Matthew Ianniello|Matthew "Matty the Horse" Ianniello]], a ''Genovese crime family'' capo operated from his restaurant ''[[Umberto's Clam House]]'' in the 1970sMcShane, Larry via [[Associated Press]]. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/04/AR2007030400559_pf.html "Matty 'The Horse' on His Last Ride"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', March 4, 2007. Accessed December 23, 2017.Vitello, Paul. [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/23/nyregion/mafia-boss-matty-the-horse-ianniello-dies-at-92.html "Matthew Ianniello, the Mafia Boss Known as ‘Matty the Horse,’ Dies at 92"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 22, 2012. Accessed December 23, 2017. "His stake in one restaurant, Umberto's Clam House, in Little Italy, placed him at the scene of an infamous and legendary gangland murder on April 7, 1972, when the reputed Colombo crime family underboss Joey Gallo was riddled with bullets between courses of a late-night meal by four gunmen, in an intrafamily gang war. Mr. Ianniello, who then owned a hidden interest in Umberto's, was working in the kitchen at the time and was initially suspected of having some involvement in the hit. But he was never charged." * [[John Gotti]], boss of the [[Gambino crime family]] operated from the [[Ravenite Social Club]] in the late 1980s into the early 1990s[[Selwyn Raab|Rabb, Selwyn]]. [https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/02/magazine/john-gotti-running-the-mob.html?pagewanted=all "John Gotti Running The Mob"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 2, 1989. Accessed December 23, 2017. "On Christmas Eve, a week after the double slaying, detectives concealed in a van in Little Italy witnessed a striking scene outside the Ravenite Social Club, Dellacroce's old headquarters, that confirmed what investigators had heard from informers: John Gotti was the new boss of the Gambino family." ==In popular culture== Little Italy was the locale of the fictional [[Corleone family|Corleone crime family]] depicted in the novel ''[[The Godfather (novel)|The Godfather]]'' and the [[Godfather Trilogy|three movies]] based on it. It is also the setting for the 1973 film ''[[Mean Streets]]'', starring [[Robert De Niro]] and [[Harvey Keitel]],Wong, Edward. [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/16/nyregion/little-italy-journal-reliving-mean-streets-in-open-air-screenings.html "Little Italy Journal; Reliving 'Mean Streets' In Open-Air Screenings"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 16, 2000. Accessed July 30, 2016. "For a taste of the old neighborhood, he had to walk over to the playground at Spring and Mulberry Streets to watch films like ''Mean Streets,'' the 1973 Martin Scorsese opus in which Harvey Keitel and Robert De Niro play small-time wiseguys in Little Italy." and the 1994 film ''[[Leon: The Professional]]'', starring [[Jean Reno]] and [[Natalie Portman]].Breihan, Tom. [https://theconcourse.deadspin.com/the-professional-is-deeply-problematic-profoundly-cool-1702737080 "''The Professional'' Is Deeply Problematic, Profoundly Cool, And Very '90s"], ''[[Deadspin]]'', May 15, 2015. Accessed December 23, 2017. "The movie opens with a camera flying over Central Park, turning into a fisheye zoom-in on the Little Italy restaurant where Reno gets his contracts. When he's on a job, Reno's face emerges from shadows, then disappears again when he's made his point." ==Other Italian American neighborhoods in New York City== {{Main|List of Italian American neighborhoods}} Other Italian American neighborhoods in New York City include: * In [[Manhattan]] - East Harlem ([[Italian Harlem]], [[Pleasant Avenue]]), [[Greenwich Village]] * In [[the Bronx]] - [[Arthur Avenue]] in [[Fordham, Bronx|Fordham]], [[Belmont, Bronx|Belmont]], [[Morris Park, Bronx|Morris Park]], [[Country Club, Bronx|Country Club]], and [[Pelham Bay, Bronx|Pelham Bay]] * In [[Brooklyn]] - [[Bensonhurst, Brooklyn|Bensonhurst]], [[Bay Ridge]], [[Dyker Heights, Brooklyn|Dyker Heights]], [[Bath Beach, Brooklyn|Bath Beach]], [[South Brooklyn]], [[East Willamsburg]] and other various neighborhoods in Brooklyn * In [[Queens]] - [[Howard Beach, Queens|Howard Beach]], [[Ozone Park, Queens|Ozone Park]], [[Middle Village, Queens|Middle Village]] and other various neighborhoods in Queens * In [[Staten Island]] - the borough has the highest proportion of Italian Americans of any county in the United States and possibly North America. Over 200,000 residents claim Italian heritage (over 40%), with [[Rosebank, Staten Island|Rosebank]] being the first Italian enclave. ==See also== {{Portal|Italy|New York City}} * [[Feast of San Gennaro]], a religious commemoration * [[Italian Harlem]] * [[List of Italian-American neighborhoods]] * [[Little Italy|List of Little Italy neighborhoods around the world]] * [[Lower Manhattan]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.thing.net/~lina/littleitaly.html Little Italy Neighbors Association] {{manhattan}} {{Little Italy}} {{Ethnicity in New York City}} {{National Register of Historic Places in New York}} [[Category:Ethnic enclaves in New York (state)]] [[Category:Italian-American culture in New York City]] [[Category:Lower Manhattan]] [[Category:Little Italys in the United States|Manhattan]] [[Category:Neighborhoods in Manhattan]] [[Category:Restaurant districts and streets in the United States]] [[Category:Historic districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Manhattan]]

revision.text:
{{advert|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Manager Tools LLC. | logo = [[File:LogoManagerTools.jpg]] | foundation = January 2005<ref>Linkedin Page for Mark Horstman http://www.linkedin.com/pub/mark-horstman/0/a3/373</ref> | founder = Michael Auzenne, Mark Horstman | location = [[United States]] | industry = Training, Management | products = Podcasts, Interview tools | services = Consulting,Conferences, Resume review, Training | num_employees = | homepage = [http://www.manager-tools.com/ www.manager-tools.com] }}
The '''Manager Tools Podcast''', founded in 2005, is a weekly audio [[podcast]] by Michael Auzenne and Mark Horstman, which focuses on career advice and helping managers become more effective.<ref name="mtAbout">Manager Tools "About us" page https://www.manager-tools.com/about-us</ref><ref name="fan">Unofficial Manager Tools Fan Club on Squidoo</ref> It was awarded People's Choice Podcast from [[Podcast Awards]] in 2008, and won the Best Business Podcast award in 2006, 2007, 2008, and 2012.In 2016, was awarded as the Legacy show in Business <ref name="awards">Podcast Award Winners 2005-2011 http://podcastawards.com/index.php?option=pastwinners</ref><ref name="pa2012">PodcastAwards page January 8, 2012. http://www.podcastawards.com/</ref>
==Hosts== The podcast hosts, Mark Horstman and Mike Auzenne, are both graduates of [[West Point]], the United States Military Academy, which is where they met.<ref name="showabout">Manager Tools podcast about their Background http://www.manager-tools.com/2005/07/the-show-about-us</ref>
Michael Auzenne spent nearly two decades in Corporate America as a manager and executive.<ref name="mike">"30- Leveraging Corporate Skills to Successful Entrepreneurship" http://strugglingentrepreneur.com/2008/03/02/wwwmanaagertoolscom-leverages-leadership-experience/%</ref> His corporate career includes executive assignments in technology and Program Management for [[MCI Inc.]] and [[Bell Atlantic]] as well as several entrepreneurial pursuits in the restaurant and retail fitness industries.
Mark Horstman was a manager and executive in sales and marketing at [[Procter & Gamble]]. Mark has been coaching and training managers and executives since 1988.<ref name="mtAbout" />
==History== Horstman and Auzenne learned about podcasting in 2005 and decided that this could be a way to disseminate their knowledge about effective management.<ref name="showabout" /> Auzenne said he didn’t want to create a model where he would only give away half of a solution and then require the audience to pay for the rest of the solution.<ref name="Mikeint">Mike Auzenne in: Manager Tools: Making Money from Podcasting article by David Spark on http://www.sparkminute.com/2009/09/29/manager-tools-making-money-from-podcasting/</ref> The co-founders have stated that they believe they can change the world by changing management, and that the way to change it is one manager at a time.<ref name="mtweb" /> After starting with the weekly free podcasts, both hosts completely dedicated their work time, and became co-founders of Manager Tools LLC, a management consulting firm.<ref name="mtAbout" /> They regularly consult to and train managers in [[Fortune 1000]] companies around the world.<ref name="careers">Career Tools Wins Business Category of People's Choice Podcast Awards http://www.eworldwire.com/pressreleases/211975</ref> Their company also sells transcripts of the podcasts on-line through membership, and they organize public and in-company conferences to practice the Manager Tools.<ref name="Mikeint"/> As of 2012, the company has five full-time employees.
The first ''Manager Tools'' podcast was published on June 26, 2005.,<ref name="mtweb" /> with the first ''Career Tools'' podcast published on December 4, 2008.<ref>Career Tools Podcast Launches on 4 December! http://www.manager-tools.com/2008/11/career-tools-podcast-launches-on-4-december</ref> The first live podcast was recorded with an audience after a conference and was published on October 31, 2010.<ref name="mtweb" /> The '''500th''' podcast of the company was published on January 1, 2012.<ref>Manager Tools Forum user post for 500th Podcast https://www.manager-tools.com/forums/500-podcasts</ref>
On January 25th, 2015 Manager Tools cast series delivered the '''500th''' episode and reached 250+Million Downloads <ref>Mark Tweet https://twitter.com/mahorstman/status/559440548461678593</ref>
The podcasts use no advertisement and most incoming links on the internet are from comments by passionate users.<ref>User comment on article, "Better ways for a company to handle layoff" http://toostep.com/idea/better-ways-for-a-company-to-handle-layoff</ref><ref>User comment on article, "LinkedIn or Lose Out" http://asq.org/quality-progress/2011/07/career-development/linkedin-or-lose-out.html</ref><ref>User comment on article, "Happy Employees: How to Create Them" http://workawesome.com/management/happy-employees/</ref><ref>User Blog post recommending Manager Tools http://dugomes.wordpress.com/2008/06/22/podcast-from-wwwmanager-toolscom-example-of-goals/</ref><ref>User comment on question, "What is the purpose of 1 on 1 ?" http://pm.stackexchange.com/questions/2715/what-is-the-purpose-of-1-on-1</ref> The tools they teach are now also being cited by education institutions.<ref>Rick Wanner, One-On-One Meetings, Leadership Laboratory Management Competencies, SANS Technology Institute http://www.sans.edu/research/management-laboratory/article/oneonone-meetings</ref> The hosts have done talks in prestigious schools such as [[Robert R. McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science]]<ref>http://www.mccormick.northwestern.edu/personaldevelopment/videos.html</ref> and [[Kellogg School of Management]]<ref>Mark Horstman Interviewing Presentation - Kellogg School http://www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/student/club/va/resources.html</ref> Most of the podcast increase in the number of listeners comes from personal recommendations as well as the effect of the [[Podcast Awards]]
Manager Tools podcast: Every Manager Effective and Career Tools podcast: Every Professional Productive are trademarks of Manager Tools LLC since September 2012.<ref name="Newsletter" />
==Podcasts== Most casts are about 30–40 minutes long, presented as a dialogue between the two hosts.<ref name="smb">http://www.smbtrendwire.com/2008/01/07/podcast-review-manager-tools/ Review at Small Business Trends Radio (2008)</ref> They cover a specific topic related to management or career development. Casts start with an overview of the points to be discussed, followed by the discussion point by point, and end with a summary of the points discussed.
Manager Tools main podcasts are available on the webpage and also through [[iTunes]] and [[RSS]] feeds.<ref>List of Manager Tools Podcasts https://www.manager-tools.com/podcasts</ref> The podcasts often refer to each other which in the past has created issues with new listeners. In order to help them, a collection of 'basics' casts has been created and is available on their website as well.<ref name="mtBasics" /> Those cover mostly 'The Management Trinity' as well as additional basic notions.
Manager Tools casts help ''90 percent of the people, 90 percent of the time''.<ref>Feedback From Your Directs - What To Say - Part 1 http://www.manager-tools.com/2012/04/feedback-your-directs-what-say-part-1</ref> And the great majority of the casts are timeless instead of just timely.<ref name="Newsletter">Mark Horstman, "Things I Think I Think" newsletter from 26 September 2012</ref>
[[Management]] is about doing the right things repeatedly. Successful managers do them over and over again; and is about '''Behaviors'''.<ref>One-on-Ones: The Single Most Effective Management Tool http://www.manager-tools.com/2005/07/the-single-most-effective-management-tool-part-1</ref>
In the Podcast, you find many topics that helps on professional life. Such as: Behaviors ('''There are 5 Manager Tools behaviors'''),<ref>The Management Trinity - Feedback http://www.manager-tools.com/2008/03/the-management-trinity-feedback</ref> career, communication, development, network, performance, strategy, team and many more. One of the Manager Tools motto is : "'''There's a cast for that'''".
*'''Manager Tools podcast''': ''Every Manager Effective''.<ref name="mtAbout" /> *'''Career Tools podcast''': ''Every Professional Productive''.<ref name="mtAbout" />
The Manager Tools '''"Basics"''' — is a special collection of podcasts on the essentials of effective managerial behavior and the base of all the Manager Tools advanced material.
The podcasts are often articulated around the 'Manager Tools Philosophy'.<ref name="showabout" /> Its main parts are ''''The Management Trinity'''' and the ''''Horstman's Laws''''. The founders focus on specific action steps that managers can apply to their job as opposed to theoretical management models.<ref>http://www.atkinsonadvisor.com/hits-bytes/www-manager-tool-com/</ref>
The hosts also provide for a fee access to special set of podcasts with more specific themes and with more detailed information on those topics, covering among other:<ref name="products">List of Manager Tools products https://www.manager-tools.com/products</ref>
* '''Interviewing Series'''<ref>Manager Tools, Interviewing Series https://www.manager-tools.com/products/interview-series</ref> * '''First Job Fundamentals'''<ref>Manager Tools, First Job Fundamentals https://www.manager-tools.com/products/first-job-fundamentals</ref>
==Notable Content and theories==
===Foundational Principles - The Management Trinity===
The hosts often refers to the ''''Management Trinity'''':<ref>https://www.manager-tools.com/2013/01/positive-feedback-before-its-time</ref> One on Ones, Feedback, and Coaching, plus their silent fourth partner, Delegation. These are at the heart of everything Manager Tools recommends.<ref>The Management Trinity http://www.manager-tools.com/2009/10/management-trinity-part-1</ref> All Of The Manager Tools Trinity Tools are ''Teachable Equivalents'' that the hosts have developed. Most casts are based on these tools.
They usually include:<ref name="mtBasics">List of Basic Manager Tools Podcasts https://www.manager-tools.com/manager-tools-basics</ref><ref>Managing Responsibilities http://www.ymresourcer.com/documents/Managing_Responsibilities.doc</ref> *One on Ones (Weekly meetings in order to reinforce relationships) - recognised as "the best business practice of all time" by profitguide.com<ref>http://www.profitguide.com/article/78170--the-30-best-business-practices-of-all-time</ref> - *Feedback (reinforcing or correcting behaviours) *Coaching (Fostering Continuous Development) *Delegation (Managerial Economics of who should do a task)
Other foundational principles as described in the 'basics' podcasts include:<ref name="mtBasics" /> * Running Effective Meetings * Methods for rolling out the Manager Tools Trinity * 'Solution to a Stalled Technical Career'
===DISC - Management adapted to the personality of the direct report=== Manager Tools podcasts often refer to the [[DISC assessment]] when adapting management and communication styles to individuals.
The DiSC model provides nonjudgmental language for exploring behavioral issues across four personality traits ('''D'''ominance, '''I'''nfluence, '''S'''teadiness and '''C'''onscientious.)<ref>http://www.inscapepartners.com/discclassic/</ref> These four traits can be grouped in a grid with "D" and "I" sharing the top row and representing extroverted aspects of the personality, and "C" and "S" below representing introverted aspects. "D" and "C" then share the left column and represent task-focused aspects, and "I" and "S" share the right column and represent social aspects. In this matrix, the vertical dimension represents a factor of "Assertive" or "Passive", while the horizontal dimension represents "Open" vs. "Guarded".<ref>[[DISC assessment]]</ref>
===Other principles=== There are also some recurring references to other 'rules' or 'laws'. These are mostly referred to verbally in the podcasts:<ref>Manager Tools Forum Post https://www.manager-tools.com/forums/hortsmans-laws-podcast</ref><ref>Manager Tools Forum Post https://www.manager-tools.com/forums/horstmans-laws-01</ref> * Horstman Curve (difficulty of growth at the beginning of a career) * McGuire's Hump (regarding how hard it is to change) * Horstman's Laws of Interviewing * Horstman's Rule of Christmas * The Wendii Curve (regarding Cultural Diversity)<ref>Manager Tools Podcast http://www.manager-tools.com/2010/02/managing-cultural-diversity-wendii-curve</ref> * Walt's Rule (regarding how and where spend time)<ref name="fan" /> * Horstman’s Law of Managerial Friction: It’s always harder to start change than it is to sustain it. * Horstman's Corollary to [[Parkinson's Law]] ("Work contracts to fit the time you give it") * Horstman's definition of conflict: more than one person in the same county.
==Activities== Manager Tools is incorporated under "Manager Tools LLC" and provides multiple services<ref name="mtweb" /> such as :
* Free Podcasts (Manager Tools, Career Tools) * Licensed Content * Forums for user discussions * Training Conferences * Corporate Engagements<ref name="manager-tools.com">https://www.manager-tools.com/organizations</ref> * Publications and other.
===Licensing===
Some casts are only accessible with a free registration. The site offers Individual Licenses.<ref name="member">Become a Member https://www.manager-tools.com/user/register?destination=user/register</ref> This is in order to fund the project and keep the podcasts advertisement-free.<ref name="Mikeint"/> Both co-founders have had multiple offers for sponsorships, but they’ve turned them all away because the advertising model doesn’t currently fit into their model and brand of building trust.<ref name="Mikeint"/>
===Forums===
The Manager Tools Forums are built for public discussions between listeners of the podcasts. Here you can read questions asked by other managers and professionals about workplace situations.<ref>Make A Decision. Manager Tools Newsletter September 18, 2012.</ref>
Forums are a part of Community in which managers and professionals interact <ref>https://www.manager-tools.com/community</ref>
Manager Tools employees (including the hosts) regularly intervene to help the members as well.
===Conferences=== Manager Tools regularly hosts training conferences around the world.<ref>List of Manager Tools Conferences https://www.manager-tools.com/training</ref> There always is a maximum number of attendees in order to maintain the quality of the delivery. They deliver four types of conferences:<ref name="mtweb">Manager Tools web site http://www.manager-tools.com</ref>
* '''Effective Manager Conference'''.<ref>http://www.manager-tools.com/effective-manager-conference</ref> * '''Effective Communications Conference'''.<ref>http://www.manager-tools.com/effective-communications-conference</ref> * '''Corporate Effective Manager Conference'''.<ref name="manager-tools.com"/> *'''Effective Interviewer Conference'''.<ref>http://www.manager-tools.com/effective-interviewer-conference</ref>
===Publications and Other Products=== Other products and tools available for free, sold or re-sold by Manager Tools include:<ref name="products" /> <ref>Manager Tools Products https://www.manager-tools.com/products</ref> <ref>https://www.manager-tools.com/tools</ref>
* '''Blogs:''' ''The Effective Manager''.<ref>Mark Horstman, "Things I Think I Think" newsletter from 16 May 2012</ref> and ''The Productive Professional'' * '''Resume:''' ''Workbook.'' * '''[[DISC assessment|DiSC®]] Profile'''.<ref>Inscape Publishing, provider of DiSC® http://www.inscapepublishing.com/</ref> * '''Interview Creation Tool''' * '''[[iOS]] and '''Android Apps''' <ref>Mark Horstman Tweet https://twitter.com/mahorstman/status/659476208514535424</ref> *'''Road Map''' Launched on 2017: Interactive [[Application software]] that brings solution to effective manager behaviors<ref>{{cite web|title=RoadMap: What's included|url=https://www.manager-tools.com/products/roadmap|website=Manager Tools website|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=What Is RoadMap?|url=https://www.manager-tools.com/faq/what-roadmap|website=Official Manager Tools}}</ref> * '''Weekly Email Publications:''' ''Things I Think I Think.''<ref>Things I Think I Think https://www.manager-tools.com/forums/things-i-think-i-think-4-mar-ethics</ref> and ''Newsletter''<ref name="member" /> * '''Licensee Conference Call.''' * '''Effective Relationships Series.''' * '''The Daily Manager.''' a partnership with [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]] ePrintCenter.<ref name="eprint">Hp Eprintcenter webpage at: https://h30495.www3.hp.com/detail/1169.2</ref> Since 2011, Manager tools also provides a mobile version of their website and for podcast navigation.<ref>Mobile Manager Tools site https://www.manager-tools.com/forums/manager-tools-mobile-devices</ref><ref name="navigator">Manager Tools Daily Manager Podcast Navigator http://www.manager-tools.com/podcast-navigator</ref>
==Internationalisation== Manager Tools, although slightly biased by US background, aims at creating timeless and universal content.<ref>Manager Tools Podcast Linkedin for Managers http://www.manager-tools.com/2010/04/linkedin-managers-part-1</ref> They have listeners all over the world;<ref name="eprint" /> since 2009, some of the podcasts and knowledge have been adapted in French<ref>Manager Tools France Launches! https://www.manager-tools.com/forums/manager-tools-france</ref><ref>Manager Tools Community https://www.manager-tools.com/community</ref> <ref>Manager Tools in french "Outils du Manager" http://www.outilsdumanager.com/</ref> and, since 2010, was also in German for some time. Those adaptations have been started by enthusiastic listeners of the cast that are willing to invest their time to make the content available to a larger audience (Cedric Watine and his associate Lorry in the French version. Gernot Glawe was in the German version).
On 12 March 2012, Gernot Glawe, who had been hosting and maintaining the German version of the site, announced its closing by the end of March 2012 and thanked his listeners for the 116.000 downloads of his 68 podcasts.
As part of internationalization, Manager Tools conferences have been, besides [[United States]], in [[Europe]], [[Australia]] and in [[China]] ([[Shanghai]]).
==Awards and Popularity== In '''2016''' Mark Horstman and Manager Tools launched "The Effective Manager" book <ref> Wiley page of the book http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1119244609.html</ref>
In '''2016''' Mark and Mike were interviewed by WSJ "How to Be a Better Manager in 30 Minutes a Week" <ref> WSJ article link https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-to-be-a-better-manager-in-30-minutes-a-week-1473784031</ref>
Manager Tools won the People's Choice [[Podcast Awards]] in the business category in 2006, 2007, 2008 and 2012. In 2008 it also won the overall People's Choice category. Career Tools won the best Business Podcast at the 2010 edition of these awards.<ref name="awards" />
Manager Tools was nominated again in 2013 in both categories Peoples Choice and Business.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.podcastawards.com/ |title=Podcast Awards site |accessdate= March 2014}}</ref>
In '''2014''', named one of Fortune's 9 great business podcasts<ref>{{cite web|title=9 great business podcasts you should know|url=http://fortune.com/2014/12/04/great-business-podcasts/|website=Fortune|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref>
In '''2014''' Mark Horstman was interviewed by MEN'S FITNESS in two occasions.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mensfitness.com/life/your-job-interview-game-plan | title=Your Job Interview Game Plan |accessdate= 2 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Earn it right way get raise|url=http://www.mensfitness.com/life/earn-it-right-way-get-raise|website=Men's Fitness|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref>
In '''2014''', Career Tools named one of the 10 Must – Watch Podcasts in Letsintern.<ref>{{cite web|title=10 Must – Watch Podcasts that you must follow to get ahead in your career!|url=http://www.letsintern.com/blog/10-podcasts-to-get-you-ahead-in-career/|website=Letsintern|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref>
In '''2014''', Manager Tools ''podcasts'' are downloaded '''2.5 million times per month'''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://twitter.com/mahorstman | title=Mark Twitter Account |accessdate= 3 March 2014}}</ref>
"The Manager Tools podcast was recognized at the 2007 Podcast and New Media Expo as the Podcast Winner for the category of Business Podcasts. This is an impressive win, considering that over 3280 sites were nominated."<ref name="struggling">"Mark Horstman- successful Entrepreneur or the next “Peter Drucker”?" http://strugglingentrepreneur.com/2008/04/11/34-mark-horstman-successful-entrepreneur-or-the-next-peter-drucker/</ref>
The Manager Tools podcast is downloaded over '''80,000''' ''times weekly'';<ref name="navigator" /> in '''140+''' ''countries worldwide''<ref name="eprint" />
The podcast is often recommended for non-native speakers wanting to improve their business English.<ref>"Better at English" English training site http://www.betteratenglish.com/advanced-listening-tip-for-students-of-business-english/</ref> This is also how Cédric Watine from the French Manager-tools "Outil du Manager" discovered the podcasts initially.<ref>"Outils du Manager" first podcast http://www.outilsdumanager.com/2009/03/moins-de-th%C3%A9orie-plus-de-management</ref>
"Although it is US based and intended for managers in the corporate world it's full of practical techniques for managing staff and organisations. It is widely applicable to managers of all kinds, and anyone who has working relationships with other people."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.community.net.nz/how-toguides/volunteering/publicationsresources/manager-tools.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-11-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419061609/http://www.community.net.nz/how-toguides/volunteering/publicationsresources/manager-tools.htm |archivedate=2012-04-19 |df= }}</ref>
Manager Tools has an unofficial fan club: "Created by satisfied listeners." Dedicated to promove the resources of the podcasts as well as to provide some color commentary and background about the show and its hosts.<ref name="fan" />
In 2008, the podcast was reviewed by Small Business Trends Radio.<ref name="smb" /> The podcast is often recommended in professional circles as a "must listen for any new manager".<ref>Linkedin user question http://www.linkedin.com/answers/management/organizational-development/MGM_ODV/949544-182969</ref>
"One of TechNewsRadio.com's favorite podcasts - Manager Tools"<ref>Tuesday, January 30, 2007 FYI - Manager Tools Inaugural Effective Manager Conference http://www.technewsradio.com/administrivia/</ref>
December 21, 2010: "Career Tools, the podcast focused on actions listeners can take to grow and enhance their careers, has won the Business Category of the People's Choice Podcast Awards. This award recognizes Career Tools commitment to providing actionable guidance to individual professionals."<ref name="careers" />
On December 12, 2011 Chriss Simmons wrote: "A podcast that, in the short time I’ve been listening to it, has already paid dividends with respect to career growth and professionalism".<ref>Manager Tools: A Goldmine of a Podcast by Chriss Simmons. Dec 12, 2011. http://chrissimmons.ca/2011/12/manager-tools-a-goldmine-of-a-podcast/</ref>
On February 4, 2011 Geschrieben von S. Hagen wrote: "For several years I hear when driving regular podcasts. One of my favorite shows is "Manager Tools" by Mark Horstman and Mike Auzenne. The two speak in refreshing simplicity and clarity about principles, principles and practices in management. Especially I would like to put your heart into the special " Horstman's Law of Project Management".<ref>Horstman’s Law of Project Management http://pm-blog.com/2011/02/04/horstmans-law-of-project-management-2/</ref> On April 17, 2012 he wrote back and recommended the podcast again.<ref>Die DNS des Projektmanagements: Wer macht was bis wann? http://pm-blog.com/2012/04/17/die-dns-des-projektmanagements-wer-macht-was-bis-wann/</ref>
On May, 2012 Pulse Magazine interviewed Mark Hosrtman about delegation and how to do it in the Manager Tools way.<ref>Ask the expert. Pulse Magazine, pages 46 and 47 http://viewer.zmags.com/publication/a0a49839?page=1#/a0a49839/49</ref>
On May 9, 2012 Rick Broida (PCWorld) named Manager Tools podcast as one of his favorite business-minded podcasts: "If you're a manager, you need this podcast".<ref>"The 7 Best Podcasts for Business Users https://www.pcworld.com/article/255305/the_7_best_podcasts_for_business_users.html</ref>
On October 17, 2012 Joshua Malin (business2community), published:"Manager Tools probably the richest source of solid information and advice on this listm Manager Tools covers specific topics like soliciting feedback, giving unfavorable performance reviews and shutting down that guy who keeps derailing your meetings."<ref>"9 Great Podcasts for Small Business Owners" http://www.business2community.com/podcasts/9-great-podcasts-for-small-business-owners-0309789</ref>
On November 7, 2012 John Dillard, an EO Charlotte member and president and partner of Big Sky Associates, Inc. published: "I found two sources of information that I can’t resist sharing because they are concise, persuasive and actionable. I’m hoping that if you’re a leader and you’re reading this post, you can put these two sources to work right away, as I am convinced that OOOs are a very important part of developing and deploying a strategy or significant change effort. The first source is Manager Tools...".<ref>One-on-Ones: A Critical Part of the Executive’s Toolkit http://blog.eonetwork.org/2012/11/one-on-ones-a-critical-part-of-the-executives-toolkit/#ixzz2DXVEB5iq</ref>
Podcast has an average of 4.5 stars in Customer Ratings on [[itunes]] with 474 ratings (2012).<ref>Itunes preview https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/manager-tools/id74198801</ref>
"If you're tired of a lot of management theory and would rather learn SPECIFIC actions you can take TODAY to improve your management performance, you'll enjoy the manager tools podcast."<ref>http://www.learnoutloud.com/Podcast-Directory/Business/Leadership-and-Management/Manager-Tools-Podcast/19447</ref>
"What sets this podcast apart from the others in the genre of Business Management is that they deliver tools, techniques, processes and steps, as well as the concepts and background needed to successfully implement the practices for excellent and effective management by Business Executives and Managers"<ref name="mike" /><ref name="struggling" />
Erik Bernskiold (web designer, consultant and software educator) named Career Tools "a golden podcast". "They do an excellent job of sharing dos and don’ts in order to sharpen your career skills."<ref>http://www.erikbernskiold.com/new-podcast-find-career-tools/</ref>
Julie Taylor (styleandtechformen) named the podcasts in her list "Top 11 Podcasts to Catch While You Can."<ref>http://www.styleandtechformen.com/top11/top_podcasts/index.html#axzz2BIJWhW5v</ref>
Jeremy Triplett article "Manager Tools: The Best Management Advice I Ever Received", published in the '''American Society of Crime Lab Directors''' (ACSLD) Executive Education Digest<ref>http://www.manager-tools.com/2013/11/manager-tools-best-management-advice-i-ever-received</ref>
David Lowe:('''Chinese Translation''' from Manager Tools’ article “Is It You Or Is It Me?”)<ref>http://actionable-itsm.com/?p=1395</ref>

revision.comment: fix formatting of birth date in text of article using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Matti Juhani Alahuhta | image = Matti Alahuhta.jpg | caption = Alahuhta in 2013 | image_size = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1952|6|22}} | birth_place = [[Alahärmä]], [[Finland]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Chairman of DevCo Partners Oy and Outotec Oyj | website = }} '''Matti Juhani Alahuhta''' (born 22 June 1952 in [[Alahärmä]], Finland) was the President & CEO of [[KONE Corporation]] (2005–2014). Earlier he worked 26 years at Nokia Corporation and was Member of [[Nokia]]´s Executive Board from 1993 to 2004. He is Chairman of the Board of DevCo Partners Oy and [[Outotec|Outotec Corporation]]. He is also Member of the Board of Directors of [[KONE Corporation|Kone Corporation]] (2003-), [[Volvo AB]] (2014-)and [[ABB Group]] (2014-).
==Biography== ===Early life and education=== Matti Alahuhta attained his M.Sc. (Tech.) in 1976 and D.Sc. (Tech.) in 1990 at the [[Helsinki University of Technology]]. His dissertation was titled "Global Growth Strategies for High Technology Challengers". Alahuhta has also earned an Honorary Doctorate from [[Tampere University of Technology]].
===Career=== Alahuhta joined [[Nokia]] as a Research Engineer in 1975. From 1982 to 1984 he was a Sales Director at [[Rank Xerox]] and he returned to Nokia as a Sales Director for the Transmissions Systems Business Unit at a time when Nokia started its global expansion in its telecommunications networks business. After different roles with increasing responsibilities, he was appointed as President of Nokia Telecommunications and as Member of the Executive Board in 1993. In 1998, he was appointed President of Nokia Mobile Phones and in 2004 he was appointed Executive Vice President and Chief Strategy Officer of the Nokia Group. Under Alahuhta's leadership from 2005 to 2014, KONE's global market share doubled and its market capitalization six folded.
===Marriage and children=== Matti Alahuhta is married to his wife Leena and they have two children.
==Awards== In 1993, Matti Alahuhta was designated as a Knight for the 1st Class of the [[Order of the White Rose of Finland]]. In 2003, he was given the Commander of the Order of the White Rose of Finland and in 2013, Commander, First Class, of the Order of the White Rose of Finland.
The European Business Press (EBP), representing 55 Europe´s leading financial and economic publications in 28 countries, presented Matti Alahuhta the "European Manager of the Year 2009 Award”.
{{Nokia}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Alahuhta, Matti}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Finnish businesspeople]] [[Category:Nokia people]] [[Category:Aalto University alumni]] [[Category:People from Kauhava]]
